body_text.text: Since December 2019, the outbreak of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), caused 53 by the novel coronavirus 2019 (SARS-CoV-2) has emerged in Hubei Province of China and 54 has spread to other parts of the world [1, 2] . The number of cases has been increasing rapidly, 55 with a case-fatality rate of 2.3% [3] . 56

Detection of SARS-CoV-2 in patient specimens is the first crucial step for the 57 guidance of treatment, effective infection control in the hospital and control of infection in 58 the community. Screening of infection in suspected cases with a nucleic acid amplification 59 test (NAAT), such as real-time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR), in respiratory 60 specimens, is recommended by the World Health Organization [4] . However, the collection 61 of nasopharyngeal and/or oropharyngeal swab specimens is a relatively invasive method and 62 the procedure might put healthcare workers at higher risk for disease transmission during 63 patients' gag reflex, cough, or sneezing. 64

The genome of SARS-CoV-2 is closely related to that of severe acute respiratory Table 1 . The prevalence of COVID-19 diagnosed by nasopharyngeal and throat 138 swab RT-PCR, and saliva RT-PCR in this study were 9.5% and 9.0%, respectively. 139

Among 19 patients diagnosed with COVID-19 by nasopharyngeal swab RT-PCR, the 140 median age was 33 (26-44) years. Fever as defined by temperature ≥37.5°C was presented in 141 3 (15.8%) patients. The mean+SD temperature was 37.0+0.5°C and the median (IQR) onset 142 of symptoms prior to the test was 3 (2-11) days. Common symptoms at presentation were 143 cough (11, 57.9%), dyspnoea (9, 47.4%), and runny nose (5, 26.3%). When compared with 144 181 patients with negative nasopharyngeal and throat swab RT-PCR, only a sore throat at 145 presentation was significantly lower in the COVID-19 patients. Other characteristics, 146 symptoms at presentation, and risk factors were not significantly different (Table 1) . 147

To determine the diagnostic test performance of RT-PCR of the saliva, RT-PCR 148 results of the nasopharyngeal and throat swabs were used as the reference standard. an early morning saliva was collected after coughing up by clearing the throat. In our study, a 167 saliva sample was the patient's self-generated, without a need for coughing up. This non-168 invasive procedure of saliva collection might be less aerosol-generating and might reduce the 169 risk of infection for health care workers working in the clinic. Although one might argue that 170 the collected specimens were possibly mixed between saliva and sputum, the chance of 171 patient's coughing up phlegm is rather low, as a recent study showed that dry cough was the 172 most common symptom presented in approximately 80% of patients at the onset of the illness 173 [14] . 174

FIGREF0.text: 65 syndrome-coronavirus (SARS-CoV), a causative agent of the severe acute respiratory 66 syndrome (SARS) [5]. Like SARS-CoV, SARS-CoV-2 employs the host-cell angiotensin-67 converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) as the main host receptor for cellular entry [6]. Previous 68 experimental studies showed a higher level of ACE2 expression in salivary glands, as 69 compared to that in the lungs [7] and that the epithelial cells lining salivary gland duct were 70 early target cells of SARS-CoV infection in rhesus macaques [8]. SARS-CoV was also 71detected in saliva samples[9]. This suggested that the salivary glands could be a potential 72 target for SAR-CoV-2 infection, and hence saliva could be a potential sample for SARS-73CoV-2 detection. 74Recently, SARS-CoV-2 viral load was demonstrated to arise near presentation onset 75[10], using a saliva sample as the specimen for the screening of the disease is appealing.-sectional study was conducted among 200 patients under investigation who 85 attended an acute respiratory infection clinic at Ramathibodi Hosptial, Bangkok, Thailand, 86 between 27 March and 4 April, 2020. The inclusion criteria were those who presented with a 87 history of fever or acute respiratory symptoms together with 1) travel history from an 88 endemic area of COVID-19 within 14 days, or 2) history of contact with an individual who 89 was confirmed or suspected having COVID-19. Patients aged less than 18 years old were 90 excluded. 91 Patient characteristics, symptoms at presentation, and risk factors were collected. As a 92 standard protocol, nasopharyngeal and throat swabs from patients were collected using Copan 93 FLOQSwabs® and a sterile tube containing Copan's Universal Transport Medium™ 94 (UTM®) (COPAN, Brescia, Italy). Prior to collecting the swabs, patients were asked to 95 provide a saliva sample, void of coughing, in a sputum collection container containing the participants. Nasopharyngeal and throat swab in a tube and saliva sample 104 from the collection container were treated with lysis buffer (bioMérieux, Marcy-l'Étoile, 105 France) to inactivate the SARS-CoV-2. Viral RNA was extracted from 200 µl of the samples 106 within 26 minutes using MagDEA  Dx reagents (Precision System Science, Chiba, Japan) 107 fully automated nucleic acid extraction system, according to the manufacturer's instructions. 108 RT-PCR workflow 109 The detection of SARS-CoV-2 in the specimens was performed by RT-PCR 110 amplification of SARS-CoV-2 ORF1ab and N gene fragments, using a SARS-CoV-2 Nucleic 111 Acid Diagnostic Kit (Sansure, Changsha, China) which was approved for detection of the 112 SARS-CoV-2 by the National Medical Products Administration (NMPA) and certified by the 113 China Food and Drug Administration (CFDA) [11]. The lower limit of detection of the test 114 was 200 copies/sample. The detection of human RNase P gene was included in the kit as a 115 control. RT-PCR was performed by the CFX96 Real-Time Detection System (Bio-Rad, 116 Hercules, CA, USA). The result was considered positive if the cycle threshold (Ct) values of 117 both target genes were ≤38, and negative when Ct values of both targets were >38. Retesting 118 was done among the samples with discordancy of the Ct values; i.e. samples with one target 119 gene with a Ct value of ≤38 and another showing a Ct value of >38. Among the retesting, the 120 specimens with repeated discordancy were reported as negative. The turnaround time of the 121 diagnosis was approximately four hours. 122 Statistical analysis 123 Data were analysed for normality and descriptive statistics were presented as a 124 number (percent) for categorical variables and mean+standard deviation (SD) or median 6 (interquartile range; IQR) for continuous variables. Chi-square or Fisher's exact test was used 126 for categorical variables. Sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), and 127 negative predictive value (NPV) and a 95% confidence interval (CI) were calculated to assess 128 diagnostic performance. The kappa coefficient [12] was used to estimate for the agreement 129 between the saliva RT-PCR and nasopharyngeal and throat swab RT-PCR results. All 130 statistical analyses were performed using Stata statistical software version 15.hundred pairs of samples of nasopharyngeal and throat swab, and saliva samples 135 were collected. Sixty-nine (34.5%) patients were male. The median (IQR) age was 36 (28-48) 136 years. Median (IQR) onset of symptoms was 3 (2-7) days. Patients' characteristics are 137 presented in

The saliva RT-PCR test demonstrated high sensitivity and 161 comparable performance to the current standard of nasopharyngeal and throat swab. The 162 kappa coefficient value showed a strong agreement of the diagnosis between the standard 163 nasopharyngeal and throat swab and the saliva sample. 164 From recent findings, SARS-CoV-2 was detected from posterior oropharyngeal saliva 165 samples, with a notable high viral load at the disease presentation [10, 13]. back_matter.text: Although testing of saliva samples might provide an advantage as a simple procedure, 175 a comparison of diagnostic study between saliva sample and confirmed-case bronchoalveolar 176 lavage (BAL) fluid or convalescence serum titre has not been available. A recent study that 177 detected the virus from multiple sites showed a lower test positivity rate from the nasal swab 178 (63%), as compared to the BAL fluid (93%) [15] . Therefore, a lower detection rate of SARS-179CoV-2 from saliva, as compared to BAL fluid among severe cases might be possible. Of 180 interest, two specimens had detectable SARS-CoV-2 from saliva samples, but not from 181 nasopharyngeal and throat swabs. Of these two samples, the Ct values of the ORF1ab and N 182 genes were 33.9 and 34.8, respectively in one specimen, and 36.2 and 33.7, respectively in 183 another specimen. These two cases later reported having anosmia. Therefore, the results of 184 these tests could represent a true infection. The yield of the saliva specimen as a 185 complementary diagnostic test for COVID-19 needs further study. 186The study has several strengths. We prospectively collected data on consecutive 187 patients who were at high risk of COVID-19 including those with acute respiratory symptoms 188 and having risk factors, thus minimising potential spectrum effect. In addition, all enrolled 189 patients were verified with the reference standard. As for the limitations, our study only
